captions.text:
If you're like most people, you probably use
butter on a fairly regular basis. Of course

there are plenty of great things you can do
with butter, but in this project, we're gonna
to be making it.

For this project I picked up a gallon of fresh
cows milk right from the cow. I let this jug

sit in the fridge overnight, and here you
can see a faint line where the cream has risen

to the top. Now if you don't have access to
a cow, you'll still be able to do this with

a heavy cream or whipping cream like this.
We need to separate the cream from the milk,

and it might seem a little counter-intuitive,
but the heaviest cream is on the top. We can

use something like a ladle to skim it off,
and transfer it to another container like

a wide mouth mason jar. Let's go ahead and
put the lid back on, making sure it's nice

and tight. And at this point, it's time to
churn the cream into butter, so start shaking.

..Now you're gonna have to shake it a lot,
and it only takes a few seconds to realize

this is going to be an amazing work out, but
if standing around shaking cream isn't your

thing, see if you can get a friend to do it
for you, or give it to your kids, and let

them work out some energy. You could even
take it with you on your morning jog. After

shaking your cream vigorously for about 3
minutes, you'll notice that it's transformed
into a light and fluffy whipped cream.
Now feel free to

take a 3 minute break. This will actually
make the process go a lot smoother, and you're

probably gonna need it. But when you get
back to shaking, shake that cream as violently

as you can. The harder and faster you shake,
the sooner you'll feel the cream break, and

when everything starts sloshing around in
the jar, you're done. This time when you look

inside, you'll see a big blob of, human powered,
homemade butter. The leftover liquid is traditional

buttermilk, and can be used for baking. My
wife used this buttermilk to make a batch

of these wholewheat buttermilk waffles. With
the buttermilk drained off, you should be

left with a beautiful ball, of golden yellow
butter. Let's compare the highest grade of

butter we found at the store, to the butter
we just made. Can you see a difference?

Now if you're like me, you'll probably want to
eat your butter right away, and that's ok,

but if you added a pinch of salt, it will
help it last longer and make it a little more

savory. I mixed in some local organic honey,
and a few other ingredients to make a delicious

honey butter, which, by the way, tastes incredible
on your buttermilk waffles. Well there are

a few ideas to support a healthier lifestyle
by shaking cream into butter. If you liked

this project, perhaps you'll like some of
my others. Check them out at www.thekingofrandom.com

title: How To Make Butter At Home - Easy Experiment!

comments.author: William Ela

comments.text:
I'm not sure heavy whipping cream will work for this.  Most of it has 
thickening and emulsifying agents in it to help it whip up, and to prevent 
it from overwhipping into butter.  I would look for a 35% m.f. cooking 
cream.

Just a note. If you let the cream warm up, it will only take a small amount 
of shaking. We tried it both cold and room temperature, and the RT one just 
took a minute or two.﻿
